Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 518, 730, 533]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 543, 576, 558]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 558, 722, 572]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 613, 861, 802]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 68, 89, 85]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 875, 100]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate a pendulum. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 112, 784, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 365, 292, 383]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[611, 365, 678, 383]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 395, 564, 413]]<|/det|> A pendulum has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 425, 139, 443]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 425, 161, 443]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 425, 875, 456]]<|/det|> Adjust the length of the pendulum until the distance \(d\) measured to the centre of the bob is \(50.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 467, 163, 486]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 467, 875, 500]]<|/det|> Displace the bob slightly and release it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 510, 163, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 510, 751, 529]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 542, 163, 560]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 542, 875, 574]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 586, 165, 604]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 586, 524, 604]]<|/det|> Calculate \(T^2\). He observes the image on the screen and says it is clearly focussed at a distance \(v = 97.9 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 605, 720, 624]]<|/det|> Calculate the new value of the focal length \(f\) of the lens using \(f = \frac{uv}{D}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[531, 694, 875, 712]]<|/det|> f = .................................................... $cm$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 704, 875, 720]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 724, 171, 742]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 724, 875, 756]]<|/det|> State and explain briefly whether the values for \(f_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(f\) in **(e)(ii)** are the same within the limits of experimental accuracy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[794, 852, 876, 871]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[794, 855, 876, 874]]<|/det|> [Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 69, 91, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 68, 875, 100]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the time taken for ice cubes in a container to melt using different insulating materials on the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 112, 400, 129]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 142, 299, 158]]<|/det|>
a copper container

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 155, 784, 173]]<|/det|>
a variety of insulating materials that can be wrapped around the copper container

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 171, 275, 186]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 186, 255, 201]]<|/det|>
a stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 200, 317, 216]]<|/det|>
a supply of ice cubes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 230, 875, 262]]<|/det|>
The student can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 275, 875, 306]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the time taken for ice cubes to melt using different insulating materials.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 320, 510, 336]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 350, 308, 365]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 378, 450, 395]]<|/det|>
· draw a diagram of the apparatus used

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 408, 589, 425]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 438, 504, 454]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 467, 875, 499]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 511, 650, 528]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 69, 534, 84]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 787, 875, 823]]<|/det|>
Permission to reproduce items where third- party owned material protected by copyright is included has been sought and cleared where possible. Every reasonable effort has been made by the publisher (UCLES) to trace copyright holders, but if any items requiring clearance have unwittingly been included, the publisher will be pleased to make amends at the earliest possible opportunity.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 829, 875, 865]]<|/det|>
To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer- related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge Assessment International Education Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet. This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cambridgeinternational.org after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 871, 875, 895]]<|/det|>
Cambridge Assessment International Education is part of the Cambridge Assessment Group. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which itself is a department of the University of Cambridge.
